thread.title: Beach walker swept away by large wave one of seven water-related Waitangi weekend fatalities
thread.title_full: Beach walker swept away by large wave one of seven water-related Waitangi weekend fatalities

author: Maddison Northcott
title: Beach walker swept away by large wave one of seven water-related Waitangi weekend fatalities
text:
Beach walker swept away by large wave one of seven water-related Waitangi weekend fatalities MADDISON NORTHCOTT Last updated 19:16, February 6 2017 Steph Rangi/Stuff.co.nz 
One person has died after four people were swept down the Waikato River near Taupo. 
A 70-year-old woman swept out to sea while walking along a West Coast beach is one of seven people killed in New Zealand waters over Waitangi weekend. 
The woman was walking along the water's edge near the mouth of the Kohaihai River, near Karamea, with her partner on Sunday when a large wave took the pair by surprise. 
Retired Karamea fire station chief Ed Tinomana said he and friend Matthew Lowe used an inflatable rescue boat to search for the woman. CHRISTEL YARDLEY/FAIRFAX NZ 
Surf life savers were out in force across the across the country to help beach goers out of "tricky situations". 
"It's a big sea, we could of zipped around here, there and everywhere." 
READ MORE: 
A rescue helicopter spotted the woman's body several kilometres north of where she was swept away and Tinomana and Lowe pulled her out of the water. STACY SQUIRES/FAIRFAX NZ 
The beginning of the Heaphy Track North of Karamea, near where a 70-year-old woman drowned after being swept out to sea by a surprise wave on Sunday. 
He said the area was well known to locals for having rough water. 
"It was a big swell, you gotta have respect for it. They used to have signs up; it's not the kind of beach you just go for a paddle in." 
He understood the couple were tourists staying in Karamea, and had been travelling in a campervan around New Zealand. 
The woman's death was one of seven over the long weekend as sweltering temperatures and clear skies saw beachgoers swarm to popular swimming spots. 
Two women, four men and a 21-month-old boy died in water-related incidents across the country â€“ triple the number of people who drowned during Waitangi weekend last year. 
Just over a month into the year, New Zealand's annual water death toll has already reached 18. 
An Auckland woman died on Monday after a group of four were swept down the Waikato River near Taupo. 
Sergeant Shane McNally said a group of friends, aged in their early 20s, were swimming in the river when the Aratiatia Dam opened. 
"Unfortunately the water has risen very rapidly and four people were swept away." 
Three made it to the riverbank, but the fourth person was found dead in one of the river's pools. 
On Sunday, emergency services were called to remote Anaura Bay, near Tolaga Bay, when a man surfaced from a dive and collapsed. He was unable to be revived. 
In Makarau, northwest of Auckland, a 21-month-old boy drowned in a swimming pool at a property. 
An Auckland Westpac Rescue Helicopter spokeswoman said emergency services performed CPR on the young boy but were unable to revive him by the time the helicopter arrived. 
Also on Sunday, a 30-year-old man died after he was found seriously injured at a beach in Eastbourne, Wellington. 
The man's friends pulled him from the water and started CPR, but he died shortly after in hospital. 
Further along the harbour, the body of a teenager who vanished in the rain-swollen Hutt River on Thursday washed up on the shores of Karaka Bay. The 19-year-old's body was spotted by a member of the public on Saturday morning. 
A man's body was found on Saturday after he went missing while diving at Dunedin's Sandfly Bay a day earlier. 
"The diver was with a group and was the only one who didn't resurface," a police spokesperson said. 
Water Safety New Zealand chief executive Jonty Mills said incidents where the victim had no intention of being in the water remained the largest cause of drowning, followed by those who went for a swim. 
Surf Lifesaving New Zealand lifesaving and education manager Henry Lawson said Cantabrians finally got some summer weather over Waitangi weekend, and while the region's beaches were busy, people "aren't getting into too much trouble". 
He had heard of a few incidents of people in Christchurch getting caught out near Sumner's Cave Rock, under the cliffs at Taylors Mistake and the New Brighton Pier. 
Swimmers should be aware of any natural or man-made objects jutting out from the water's edge, as that was where rips usually circulated, he said. 
"The water looks the same as everywhere else but a few factors combine and people realise they aren't in the situation they want to be in," he said. - Stuff
